switch statement

Using the switch statement allows you to write if ~ else if blocks more concisely. It uses the following syntax:

switch(base_expression)
{
case condition_expression1 :

case condition_expression2 :

:
:

default:

:
:
}

An expression is written in base_expression, and this expression is evaluated first. Expressions are also written in the condition_expression? following each case label within the switch block.
Each condition_expression? is evaluated sequentially within the block. If the evaluation result matches the base_expression, execution starts from that point. If it does not match condition_expression?, the lines and statements written in between are ignored. Additionally, once a match is found, subsequent case and default labels are ignored (until execution continues or is broken).
The default: label can be omitted, but if default is specified, the lines and statements following it will be executed if no match is found.
To exit the block, use break;. Be careful, as forgetting to write break and having execution continue into the next case is a common mistake.


Example:
    switch(a)
    {
    case 0:
        inform("a is 0");
        break;
    case 1:
        inform("b is 1");
        break;
    case 2:
        inform("b is 2");
        break;
    default:
        inform("b is neither 0, 1, nor 2");
    }


    switch(a)
    {
    case 0:
    case 1: // Since there is no break, case 0 will fall through here
        inform("a is 0 or 1");
        break;
    case 2:
        inform("a is 2");
    } // Since there is no default, nothing is executed for values other than 0, 1, or 2


    switch(a)
    {
    case b+1: // Expressions can also be specified after case
        inform("a==b+1");
        break;
    case c+b:
        inform("a==c+b");
    }

    switch(str)
    {
    case "abcde": // Strings can also be specified
        type=1;
        break;
    case "fghij":
        type=2;
        break;
    }
